>>21391668
Letter to Franz Overbeck 5/24/78:
>I gather from your brief allusions that our old friend Nietzsche has been holding himself aloof from you as well. There is no doubt that very striking changes have taken place in him; but anyone who observed him and his psychic spasms years ago could almost be justified in saying that a long-dreaded and not entirely unpredictable catastrophe had now overtaken him. I have retained sufficient friendship for him not to read his book – which I glanced through as I was cutting the pages – and can only wish and hope that he will thank me for it some day.

Letter to Franz Overbeck 10/19/79:
>How could I ever forget this friend of mine who was driven from me so forcefully? Although I constantly had the feeling that, at the time of his association with me, Nietzsche’s life was ruled by a mental spasm, and although it was bound to strike me as odd that this spasm could have produced so spiritually radiant and heart-warming a fire as was manifest in him to the astonishment of all, and although, finally, the ultimate decision which he reached in the inner development of his life filled me with the utmost horror when I saw how intolerable a pressure that spasm was finally causing him – I must no doubt also admit that in the case of so powerful a psychic process it is simply not possible to argue along moral lines and that one’s only response can be a shocked silence.

The concept of Will to Power is an accurate explanation of human motivation
Motivations are goal-oriented and you experience positive motivation when your desires are facilitated; that which facilitates a goal is the means, the means = power
I do believe he was slightly incorrect when he defined "bad" as "all that proceeds from weakness" in the Antichrist. His error can be obviously illustrated in the fact that if his definition of bad is to be taken seriously it becomes impossible to love an infant. What he did get right was when he said "happiness is when power increases; a resistance is overcome". Resistance is the opposite of power, and power is that which overcomes resistance. Resistance is generated out of weakness when weakness impedes on a goal, but that is conditioned by the goal and not by weakness itself. By reevaluating "bad" as "resistance" perspectivism becomes fully realized due to the fact that both "power" and "resistance" are conditioned by the goal.

posts.com: In The Philosophy of Right, Hegel, in commenting on British law, basically says Anglos do not have law as such but rather a system of judges who act as moral authorities. Could anyone here shed some light on what he meant?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Don't know how serious you're being, but the difference between common law in Britain and civil law in continental Europe is a very commonplace concept. Broadly speaking, the former emphasises judge and jury discernment and agency in applying the law, whereas the latter is more legalistic and textual. You'll notice the constitutions of the respective countries work in a similar fashion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21387898
Depends on the book. "Nine Stories" (the first time I read it, anyway) really changed how I thought about how that Hemingwayish, semi-minimalist sort of prose can work, and especially about how dialogue-heavy stories can work. For me, Salinger is the gold standard when it comes to dialogue. Encountering Salinger's incredibly effective use of dialogue has motivated me to sharpen my ear a bit.

On the other hand, books like "The Hobbit" and "Treasure Island" I read mainly for pleasure and escapism, and to screen them so I know whether they're worth recommending to my kid when he's old enough to read them.

Other books, like the book on Vedanta, were read just for educational purposes. I didn't know much about Vedanta before I read the book, and now that I've read the book I know the basics.

Others were just all-around duds. ("Circe," "The Plains")

>what is google?
>how do i type annas-archive

Anna’s Archive is a non-profit, open-source search engine for “shadow libraries”. It was created by Anna, the person behind the Pirate Library Mirror, which is a backup of the Z-Library shadow library. She felt that there was a need for a central place to search for books, papers, comics, magazines, and other documents.

We strongly believe in the free flow of information, and preservation of knowledge and culture. With this search engine, we build on the shoulders of giants. We deeply respect the hard work of the people who have created the various shadow libraries, and we hope that this search engine will broaden their reach.

This is very much a "v0". In its current state this website has many, many flaws. Since Z-Library was taken down, we rushed to get this up and running, to make the Z-Library collection accessible again.

To stay updated on our progress, follow Anna on Twitter or Reddit.

>>21375014
Wood is suggesting ridiculous because he is mad McCarthy prefers scientists to writers. A Race car driver or a violinst dropping long monologues on math and philosophy would offend Wood more than anyone else, you just know. Irrespective of whether McCarthy can produce a new mathematical discovery to give his characters the 'realism' of genius (he cannot), it would be a travesty in a novel. You can be sure the Wood types would be the first one to lamblast such an endeavour as "posing". The books are already hard enough for the common reader (and for Wood, he cleverly avoids dropping anything as much an opinion about said theories), scribbling equations in it would fail the enterprise entirely. Besides, the books are about the philosophy-science junction and unironically Lawrenxe Krauss had a good discussion with McCarthy on how a scientist might find the books interesting.

>I wish Stella Maris was chopped up and plugged into this book in a sensible way though.
I think CM originally tried to do that, basically, but it was all too big and tangled as a single novel.

If you wanted to do it, I think the best shot would be to have Alicia's talks with the Kid in strict order [i.e. Chicago farewell last] followed by her Stella Maris transcripts, all interleaved with Bobby's story in 1980+. You could stick with Alicia's suicide as the very first thing but then go straight to Bobby's dive to the plane. (Starting The Passenger with a prologue and then a chapter, both in italics, was not good, in my opinion. You want to alternate italics & normal.) That way you just have two timelines, alternating. Not sure if you want to end with the last Stella Maris transcript or Bobby's last thoughts.

You would probably want to shrink/compress the Alicia-Kid talks, if you're adding SM. That would be OK with me since they get a bit annoying anyway.

Well CM has several times described SM as a "coda" to TP which suggests he imagines it read afterwards. But I think if you read the two novels several times and ponder them, you won't end up thinking of them like that. You'll end up thinking of them both existing simultaneously.

It's a bit like, say, Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier. When you hear the pieces, you have to hear one after the other, because that's how your consciousness works. But if you listen to them over the course of a lifetime, they all end up existing simultaneously for you.

posts.name: Anonymouṡ
posts.com:
>>21377577
>Very isolating story for me. Chapter X was ridiculously melancholic. One line above all others has stuck with me from this book, trying to understand its meaning.

>“And when they crash through the walls howling?”

Ever since the border trilogy Cormac's books have been saying that Bad Times Are A-Coming. I think he genuinely believes that Western civilization is on the way out and we're going back to a cruder, more savage existence. He uses Mexico (or, more generally, Latin America) as the symbol of what will prevail:

— Cities of the Plain
When Eduardo taunts John Grady at the end, he says, more-or-less, "we [i.e. Mexico] will bury you".

— No Country For Old Men
It's right there in the title. And it's basically all Bell talks about.

— The Counselor
"The slaughter to come is probably beyond our imagining" says Malkina in the final scene. She's the ruthless hunter who is going to inherit the earth, and where's she from? Argentina. The "civilized" USA is going down. The Couselor himself is basically the average smug American normie, and he sleepwalks to destruction. Brad Pitt's character is more aware of how things really are, but this doesn't save him. (What's his name? Westray.)

Malkina is quite up-front with Reiner about this. "When the axe comes through the door, I'll already be gone, you know that?" Very similar to the line you quoted. CM really believes there are violent forces being held at bay which must eventually break through.


In The Passenger, everyone Bobby talks to expresses the same idea:

"The horrors of the past lose their edge, and in the doing they blind us to a world careening towards a darkness beyond the bitterest speculation."
— Sheddan, Chapter V

"Have you looked around lately, Son? What do you think is coming? Christmas?"
— Borman, Chapter VI

"You think his patience is infinite? I think we're probably almost there. I think the odds are on that we'll still be here to see him wet his thumb and lean over and unscrew the sun."
— Jeffrey, Chapter VIII

The difference is that now it's on a cosmic, religious scale, rather than a civilizational one. Alicia is hyper-sensitive to this, so she actually hallucinates demons at the gate, waiting their moment. She sees literally what Cormac himself sees metaphorically. Bobby doesn't see it quite as she does, but in the line you quote, he's remembering what she said and thinking she might be right.

posts.name: Anonymouṡ

>>21386300
I read The Passenger the day it came out. I didn't buy Stella Maris, because I asked for it for Christmas, but I finally cracked and downloaded an illegal epub last night. I was planning to read just the first two or three chapters but obviously I read the first seven.

Quick initial thoughts:

— Stella Maris is more even in quality than The Passenger, and more disciplined. (It has fewer moments you feel are there just because Cormac wanted to write them). If I were Cormac's editor I would have cut 20-30 pages from TP, but little or nothing from SM.

— The worst of TP is worse than the worst of SM.

— The best of TP is better than the best of SM.

— TP more or less works on its own, but SM doesn't at all. If you could keep only one, it would be TP.

— The project as a whole is a lot more successful than I expected. (That serves me right for having any faith in critics & advance readers. They're all idiots.) CM did a fine job of making a novel (two novels) out of basically un-novelish material.

— Cohen is slightly annoying because he isn't sharp enough. I understood at least half the things Alicia said that he didn't. (Maybe that was Cormac's intention — make Alicia more intelligent than the reader, and Cohen less so. It worked for Arthur Conan Doyle.)

— Alicia is likeable. Her worst habit is constantly saying "I know" when Cohen says "I don't understand". She sounds like a smart-aleck twelve-year-old taking a euphemism/colloquialism literally. She's meant to be a bit like that but not that much. I think Cormac slightly misjudged it.

— The two books should be a single volume, as originally intended. Cut down the Alicia-Kid banter sessions and have the SM transcripts after them, all alternating with Bobby's narrative. Get rid of the duplicate stuff (there isn't much). You would end up with one 550-page novel instead of a 400-page novel with a 200-page appendix. Begin with Alicia's suicide & end with Bobby's last five pages. It would be much better.

I don't think I was really giving any terrible secrets away given what's been said in the thread already. If I did, apologies.


>The final letter is (presumably) Alicia saying that she's going to kill herself
I'm not talking about Alicia's final letter. There's no great mystery about that. I mean this exchange in Stella Maris:

You didnt go to your mother’s funeral?
No.
What did your family say? Did your brother go?
Yes. Of course. I was twelve. I was going through a religious crisis. I did not want to sit through a High Mass featuring my mother’s coffin in the center aisle of the church. I couldnt.
What did your brother say?
He kissed me on the cheek and whispered to me that he loved me and that it was all right. And then it was.
And then it was.
Yes. Look. It’s a broken record. I’m doing this for you, not for me. I was given a letter to deliver and told not to read it. And I read it. And I cant unread it. Time’s up.
Oh. Yes. Of course.

I'm beginning to think the letter she describes here is metaphorical. She might be making a literary reference I'm missing.


>we're supposed to assume that Bobby got the violin and pawned it off to fund his NEETdom in Spain.
Perhaps. When he goes back to the clinic for the last time and gets Alicia's stuff she's left him a check for $23,000. That might be enough to survive on for a long time in nowhereland in 1980, if he lives rent-free at the windmill. (The owner is some vague friend of the family, and maybe he acts as a sort of caretaker, looking after it?) It's unclear and I don't know why CM was so coy about it.

>Thomas Love Peacock (18 October 1785 – 23 January 1866) was an English novelist, poet, and official of the East India Company. He was a close friend of Percy Bysshe Shelley and they influenced each other's work. Peacock wrote satirical novels, each with the same basic setting: characters at a table discussing and criticising the philosophical opinions of the day.
>Peacock's own place in literature is pre-eminently that of a satirist. That he has nevertheless been the favourite only of the few is owing partly to the highly intellectual quality of his work, but mainly to his lack of ordinary qualifications of the novelist, all pretension to which he entirely disclaims. He has no plot, little human interest, and no consistent delineation of character. His personages are mere puppets, or, at best, incarnations of abstract qualities such as grace or beauty, but beautifully depicted.

posts.com:
If poetry only gets mangled in translation, then the solution is to just read prose.

Sing, O goddess, the anger of Achilles son of Peleus, that brought countless ills upon the Achæans. Many a brave soul did it send hurrying down to Hades, and many a hero did it yield a prey to dogs and vultures, for so were the counsels of Jove fulfilled from the day on which the son of Atreus, king of men, and great Achilles, first fell out with one another.

And which of the gods was it that set them on to quarrel? It was the son of Jove and Leto; for he was angry with the king and sent a pestilence upon the host to plague the people, because the son of Atreus had dishonoured Chryses his priest. Now Chryses had come to the ships of the Achæans to free his daughter, and had brought with him a great ransom: moreover he bore in his hand the sceptre of Apollo wreathed with a suppliant's wreath, and he besought the Achæans, but most of all the two sons of Atreus, who were their chiefs.

"Sons of Atreus," he cried, "and all other Achæans, may the gods who dwell in Olympus grant you to sack the city of Priam, and to reach your homes in safety; but free my daughter, and accept a ransom for her, in reverence to Apollo, son of Jove."

On this the rest of the Achæans with one voice were for respecting the priest and taking the ransom that he offered; but not so Agamemnon, who spoke fiercely to him and sent him roughly away. "Old man," said he, "let me not find you tarrying about our ships, nor yet coming hereafter. Your sceptre of the god and your wreath shall profit you nothing. I will not free her. She shall grow old in my house at Argos far from her own home, busying herself with her loom and visiting my couch; so go, and do not provoke me or it shall be the worse for you."

The old man feared him and obeyed. Not a word he spoke, but went by the shore of the sounding sea and prayed apart to King Apollo whom lovely Leto had borne. "Hear me," he cried, "O god of the silver bow, that protectest Chryse and holy Cilla and rulest Tenedos with thy might, hear me oh thou of Sminthe. If I have ever decked your temple with garlands, or burned your thigh-bones in fat of bulls or goats, grant my prayer, and let your arrows avenge these my tears upon the Danaans."

Thus did he pray, and Apollo heard his prayer. He came down furious from the summits of Olympus, with his bow and his quiver upon his shoulder, and the arrows rattled on his back with the rage that trembled within him. He sat himself down away from the ships with a face as dark as night, and his silver bow rang death as he shot his arrow in the midst of them. First he smote their mules and their hounds, but presently he aimed his shafts at the people themselves, and all day long the pyres of the dead were burning.

Hedonism is the ideal philosophy of life, you just need to do it right.
Escapism isn't really related to hedonism. I guess it could be if you're in solitary confinement. But if you're free, it's just the wrong way to go.
Hedonism done correctly maximizes the pleasure you take from life. A hedonist enjoys good food, he'd rather eat something delicious than go on a spartan diet. But he knows there are limits that must be respected, as overindulgence in good food will cause health problems, as well as reduce the actual pleasure you get from the food itself.
So too can we apply this to what you call escapism. Escaping from the worries of the material world, in whatever form this may be done, is not in itself necessarily a fault, it is indeed a pleasure to be able to get away from the shackles of reality for some time, i'd deign to say that it is quite reasonable and healthy to do so. However, the wise hedonist would know well, that there is a limit here once again. For when you overindulge yourself in this refuge, when you are forced to return to reality, as - inevitably you will be, you will find it hard to adjust to the realities of our material plane and could be filled with a sense of confusion and despair. Thusly, i state to you, a delicious meal will bring pleasure and satisfaction with the right dosage, so will "escapism". Indeed, i've said nothing new: the golden rule, as wise men have millennia ago declared, is moderation.

>On the contrary, the German Generals insists unanimously in 1939 that they were not equipped for war and that many years must pass before “rearmament in depth” had been completed."
This is true, but not for the reasons you think. They had boosted their personnel from approximately 100,000 regulars (fully equipped) up to approx. 13 million regulars through WW2. This force was spearheaded by relatively small but fully operational armored divisions, which for the most part had their basic combat effectiveness close to 100%, because they had the necessary tanks, equipped with newly produced radio gear, already produced by German industry. What was required by the infantry and motorized divisions was transports, let alone armored transports, in a huge quantity given the relative size of the infantry compared to the mechanized. This was a quantity which could not be supported even when the entire German economy was fully deployed, which is why the majority of the German "motorized" divisions (IIRC the figure was between 70-80% in 1941) were using horses and horse-drawn guns pulling them through Russia. The armored spearheads were highly effective and German soldiers already had small arms, the problem was producing such a large quantity for such a large force in such a small time (ultimately 1933 - 1939, but more realistically it was 1936 - 1939), which is what the generals were referring to. They were always scared that the armor would outpace the infantry and cause severe catastrophes due to encirclement (which didn't happen at the start of the war due to the disorganization of France, Britain and Russia, as well as the skill of German spearheads and special operations units). I don't see what the rest of your post is trying to dispute with respect to what I originally said.

Humility leads a Christian to recognize their weakness, which is the first step towards overcoming it.

I do acknowledge that a kind of degenerate bourgoeois Christianity abounds in a worship of weakness and sentimentality, and this was probably what Nietzsche railed against most. But this is a misunderstanding of what Christianity really is. Weakness has no value in itself. Christians recognize their own relative weakness because they are closer to absolute omnipotence, not because they're actually weaker than pagans.

Is it weak to be willing to lay down one's life for the sake of love? Rather, the will which is capable of such a feat (remaining steadfast in the face of death and unspeakable tortures) is much stronger than one weakened by pagan otium and perverted by pagan pride... or really, stronger than any will which is not strengthened by supernatural grace.

Kübler-Ross' On Death and Dying and look into anthropologists that covered the topic of death and how various civilizations thought about the subject and what value it held in their respective cultures, it's a fascinating subject. >>21393450
It basically breaks down psychological mechanisms of death and why we, humans, are so paralyzed with that fear and how it dictates our every action more or less, our every drive, dream, ambition, goal, etc. It explores it through the lens of Freud and post-freudians, and Kierkegaard's cosmic heroism, while providing a framework for how you can come to terms with your own mortality and how you should embrace death as an everyday faucet of life. It's a great book, despite being written in the 70s and that impacting all the psychological research he resorts to, there's a lot of valuable insight that Beckett offers here and it's truly a worthwhile read.

>As regards the legal equality of husband and wife in marriage, the position is no better. The legal inequality of the two partners, bequeathed to us from earlier social conditions, is not the cause but the effect of the economic oppression of the woman. In the old communistic household, which comprised many couples and their children, the task entrusted to the women of managing the household was as much a public and socially necessary industry as the procuring of food by the men. With the patriarchal family, and still more with the single monogamous family, a change came. Household management lost its public character. It no longer concerned society. It became a private service; the wife became the head servant, excluded from all participation in social production. Not until the coming of modern large-scale industry was the road to social production opened to her again – and then only to the proletarian wife. But it was opened in such a manner that, if she carries out her duties in the private service of her family, she remains excluded from public production and unable to earn; and if she wants to take part in public production and earn independently, she cannot carry out family duties. And the wife’s position in the factory is the position of women in all branches of business, right up to medicine and the law. The modern individual family is founded on the open or concealed domestic slavery of the wife, and modern society is a mass composed of these individual families as its molecules.
https://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1884/origin-family/ch02d.htm

>Marxists today consider the institution of marriage or monogamy to be unequal and another form of division of the proletariat
because those relationships are unequal in capitalist society. Men generally spend more hours in paid work than women. Women are often forced to seek employment by the meagreness of their partner's wage. But since they are trying to earn a mere increment on top of their partner's wage, an additional sum to secure the family's survival, they don't need to be as picky with their choice of employment as men - they take up part-time, poorly remunerated jobs. Men, by contrast, need to earn enough to function as the primary 'breadwinner' so that their wives can look after the household. Women are also paid less for the same work because, with their tendency to get pregnant and/or take time off to raise their children, they are a riskier business proposition. Suffice it to say this situation is not the case everywhere, but a generalisation.

This places women in a very unenviable position. They must shoulder the 'double burden' of housework (including childrearing) and wage-work, whereas men can focus more exclusively on their jobs. The role of women as childrearers has largely been inherited from previous modes of production; exactly why women ended up in this position is a question to be investigated historically, something which Engels attempts in The Origin of the Family. Capital found, at first, an industrial workforce consisting largely of men - but it soon drew women and even children into its maelstrom.

Communists do not care about the sexual preferences of people, but it is clear that once the division of labour has been abolished, the family and gender relations will change significantly.

>Yet, when it was written, we could not have called it a socialist manifesto. By Socialists, in 1847, were understood, on the one hand the adherents of the various Utopian systems: Owenites in England, Fourierists in France, [See Robert Owen and François Fourier] both of them already reduced to the position of mere sects, and gradually dying out; on the other hand, the most multifarious social quacks who, by all manner of tinkering, professed to redress, without any danger to capital and profit, all sorts of social grievances, in both cases men outside the working-class movement, and looking rather to the “educated" classes for support. Whatever portion of the working class had become convinced of the insufficiency of mere political revolutions, and had proclaimed the necessity of total social change, called itself Communist. It was a crude, rough-hewn, purely instinctive sort of communism; still, it touched the cardinal point and was powerful enough amongst the working class to produce the Utopian communism of Cabet in France, and of Weitling in Germany. Thus, in 1847, socialism was a middle-class movement, communism a working-class movement. Socialism was, on the Continent at least, “respectable”; communism was the very opposite. And as our notion, from the very beginning, was that “the emancipation of the workers must be the act of the working class itself,” there could be no doubt as to which of the two names we must take. Moreover, we have, ever since, been far from repudiating it.

>>21391464
Long story short, for Deleuze, "Fascism" is when some kind of singularity directs all flows in society. The result is that society becomes monomaniacal. The only possible deviation, change, etc, then, is the destruction of society. His example is the USSR: after a certain point, the only possible action that one could take in regards to the USSR was destroying it. The metaphor of the Warrior Caste rejecting the Priestly Caste is apt: a warband that no longer fights for a cause, but simply to fight. When they run out of enemies, who will they fight? Each other. When the last enemy is dead, the last warrior will have no one to fight but himself. "Microfascism" is the potential in any given thing that demands totalitarianism (that is, demands to be the CENTRAL thing in society that defines EVERYTHING) to become a macrofascism. You can see this in a lot of SJW stuff, like Woke activists demanding that the entirety of society be viewed through their special snowflake intersectionalism ("blxck trans jewish bodxs of coloxr"). But, it's also present in Christianity, in literal actual Italian Fascism (which was literally about totalitarianism of the state), etc. Microfascisms aren't so much something to be rooted out as much as they are something to be untangled, as any microfascism is deriving from some kind of issue that, when untangled, resolves itself. There's some kind of kernel embedded in each, and that kernel causes agitation, which builds up as the microfascism, which becomes the pearl in the clam. Neutralize the kernel, and you neutralize the threat.

This, alongside his rejection of Freud, rejection of the Labor Theory of Value, and rejection of Marxist historiography, is one of the takes that got him excommunicated from Communism. He wasn't really a Liberal, but more so a Classical Republican. His ideal society is one with several overlapping centers, each of which is actually incomplete to some degree (and thus cannot become totalitarian because each center cannot actually totalize society), and thus is reliant upon the others. Society can never be totalized, meaning that it's always in a state of organic, virile flux, producing novelty and rejuvenating itself. If you want to see what this looks like, imagine Ancient Greek city states plus what the Chinese do with Daoism/Buddhism/Confucianism but with like six more religious traditions.

It should be noted that Nazism is less Fascist than actual literal Fascism, or, humorously, Christianity and Feminism, as Nazism was still rooted in (what Deleuze would call the) Pre-Signifying Regime. In essence, because Nazism was still rooted to the biological realities of race and the spiritual realities of religion, it had less potential to become totalitarian than actual literal Fascism, because the ideology was still bound to something real (constructed =/= unreal). Nazism didn't define Germanness, it instead drew its definition from somewhere else.

NSDAP kitsch neoromanticism was an overreaction to Weimar kitsch modernism:
>Berlin transformed itself into the Babel of the world. Germans brought to perversion all their vehemence and love of system. Made-up boys with artificial waistlines promenaded along the Kurfustendamm. Even ancient Rome had not known orgies like the Berlin transvestite balls, where hundreds of men in women's clothes, and women in men's clothes, danced under the benevolent eyes of the police. Amid the general collapse of values, a kind of insanity took hold of precisely those middle class circles which had been unshakeable in their order. Young ladies proudly boasted that they were perverted: to be suspected of virginity at 16 would have been a disgrace in every school in Berlin.
(Stefan Zweig)

It was built on basically sound principles (a healthy people has a healthy culture and vice versa) but the people implementing those principles were necessarily people "coarse" enough to seize the reins and do the implementing. All the better, more subtle ones with basically the same ideals were either too effete and modernist themselves (like Junger) or too bourgeois, too unwilling to be truly revolutionary (the Jungkonservativen around Papen/Schleicher). Waste time in a crisis by waiting for the perfect solution, and you get the second best solution: the NSDAP. Doesn't really matter anyway, since it would have levelled out, like all movements do, and produced a basically sane political consensus, like all movements do. Read Evola's Notes on the Third Reich for an overview of this perspective, it's good.

The Fascist regime was the same thing. Mussolini knew he was sitting on a powder keg of fifteen different kinds of well-meaning retards like the Futurists who all disagreed with each other on details, and only agreed in one thing: Italy needs a future that is non-bourgeois, non-parliamentary, non-faggy, non-Weimar. So Mussolini did the only thing one can do, and realized his job was to bind all these retards together into a mighty faggot and wait until the best tendencies among them can trickle down into a new generation not raised under Weimar conditions. Mussolini's main political strategy for Fascist Italy wasn't the implementation of any one autistic program, it was "durare," "to last/survive," i.e. to last long enough that the healthy impulses can percolate into the body politic and reawaken it, while the unhealthy and disintegrative impulses are purged. I give credit for this interesting point to fascistanon who posted about it recently.

Judging the fascist states by what they did in their first 10 years of existence is like judging France by the Terror or judging America by all its early expediencies and mistakes (it had its own Terror for example and suppressed its "internal" rebels during its own rebellion against Britain). Revolutions are always messy, the fascist revolutions are no exception. Weimar's foundation was also an unprincipled clusterfuck mess.

HERMAN: Times were tougher back then. Many souls were lost at sea. Accidents still happen these days – God knows accidents still happen – but it's much easier to know when the sea is going to be rampant, only kicks and hooves, so the boys know when it's time to stay home bothering their missus, watching TV and playing canasta with the parents. It's the technology, my girls, I’m sure you know. Satellites, weather buoys, telecommunication, all this helps to play chess with the sea. But in the end no one knows the consciousness of the ocean. There are days when he's in his pajamas, yawning, so calm you could squeeze him into a bottle and feed him to a baby. But sometimes, without warning, he becomes so ferocious that all his waters seem to be made from the frothy marrow drawn from the bones of some monster. I've already caught a sea like that, when I was a fisherman. I'll tell you, my little cherries, it's not a pretty thing to look at, it's not a pretty thing. You seem to be trapped between two hells: the sky and the sea. You look at the waters below the boat and it doesn't look like water, it looks more like a school of shark's teeth, each drop a sharp tooth, all tingling and jumping and writhing in flocks of nervous effervescence. It's like old Neptune's gastric juices when he has heartburn. Then you look up at the heavens, at the clouds, and that thing up there, that greasy gray fur, that doesn't look like air, it looks more like a sticky swamp, and you swear it would be easier for you to see sharks and whales crawling through the clouds than a rescue helicopter tearing its way through that mangrove swamp. The world goes dark. The sun, the heart of the day, is clogged with the cholesterol of the salty fog, stuffed with a swelling of spongy syrup, and for that reason it disappears and becomes silent and no longer pumps out light. There is only light in lightning. There is so much thunder and lightning in the sky that it looks like a cleaning lady is scrubbing and rinsing the floors of the Heights with a bucket of bubbling thunderbolts. North, south, east, west, above and below, night and day, sky and sea: it seems that God shouted in Nature's nape and she, in enormous fright, mixed up all the cards in the deck, and no longer knows who is who. It is at these times that you feel a chill inside your bones, as if the blood of all the drowned who moan under the waters were now crying inside you. You try to seek comfort in your teammates, perhaps hearing a “Courage boys! Hear how the world rumbles and roars! God help them, but I feel sorry for the fellows who are now out there in the dry and don't know how beautiful the world is when it gets angry!”, you try to share crumbs of faith with your crew, but looking at them you see that what was once their faces now is a terrified deformity, their eyes are balls of horror, and it seems that fear itself would be afraid to sit on heads like that.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21391417

At these times you feel that the sea is nobody's home, that everyone who wets their paws is visiting it, that everyone who lives in it, that even those who are born in it, that everyone, without exception, is an invader. The fellow having scales, fins and gills is not sufficient for a residence visa. It even seems that God has ripped a piece of the wrath out of his heart and covered three-quarters of the globe with it. Lord's mercy, my little plums, I'm not crazy, but I admit a man does get weird thoughts like that when he's caught in a storm. The waters seem to hate everything and everyone. I swear to you, my girls, I swear that once, after I returned to land without having died in a storm in which I should have died, I swear that when I walked around the island in the next few days it seemed to me that, from the fat, bovine seals raising their whiskered snouts skyward to the tiny crabs sniffing the air with their antennae, and perhaps even the fish larvae pulsing and wriggling inside their eggs, it seemed to me that all ocean dwellers spent a good part of their day, every single day, chanting prayers in honor of the Divinity and giving thanks for having managed to survive another handful of hours inside that hatred of God that we call the ocean.

2/2

Q. How do I get smart?

>The Bible
Childhood

>singing Hymns as a family
>Native American Myths

>Arthurian Myths
>Tales of Robin Hood
>Russian Folk Tales
>Watership Down
>The Redwall Series
>Tales of Charlemagne and his knights
>Japanese Myths
>Chinese Myths
>The Outsiders
>Shakespeare's Comedies
>The Giver
>The Hobbit; J.R.R.Tolkien

>Buddhist Philosophy (Predominantly Japanese)
>Daoist Philosophy
>Strangely, the Harry Potter novels - which I had never read before and did at the behest of a woman - only as bedside comfort reading mind you, but I enjoyed them.
>The Alice tales; Lewis Carroll - not so much for the tales themselves, as for Carroll's immaculate storytelling
>Essays of E.B. White
>Pride and Prejudice; Jane Austen - my greatest lesson in literary patience. I was loathing the book for a full two hundred pages, as I recall, only to come to love it in the end.
Adulthood
>The Bible - all of it. I'll be rereading it this year; God willing at a pace of ten chapters or so per day - which should finish it off in about three months as I read the other works on my list.
>The works of W.B. Yeats
>The works of Lord Alfred Tennyson
>Plato's Dialogues
>Aristotle's works, especially his Poetics, ethically related works, and governance related works
>Epictetus
>Hesiod
>Hamlet - It keeps meaning more and more to me as I get older.
>Letter from a Birmingham City Jail; MLK Jr. - that one of the most beautiful appeals in the English language could have been written on toilet paper by a man wrongly imprisoned and patronizingly chastised by his peers... Amazing and inspiring. It has been worth returning to.
>The Irish Myths - having outgrown most others, the Irish Myths remain important for me.
>The poetry of John Ashbery
>Aeschylus
>Milton
>Chaucer - whom I read in late adolescence, but who didn't matter much to me then.
>John Paul Satre's, Age of Reason

I could go on listing and listing, but I've listed too much already. If no one wishes to share this much of themselves, I would understand, or if it is too much of a burden to do such introspection and exposition, but still, it would be enlightening for us all I think. You can see a man in the history of his prized tomes.

>>21395463
I recommend starting with either his pulitzer prize winning poem, and a perusing a few on Poetry Foundation, or - if you're willing to read a lot - starting with his early poems and working through, even selectively. The LOA volumes are great for this - though I disapprove of them since they include Ginsburg among the canon. He develops substantially through the years, and his early poems are still great. Here's a sample:

Two Trees (1956)

These are amazing: each
Joining a neighbor, as though speech
Were a still performance.
Arranging by chance

To meet as far this morning
From the world as agreeing
With it, you and I
Are suddenly what the trees try

To tell us we are:
That their merely being there
Means something; that soon
We may touch, love, explain.

And glad not to have invented
Such comeliness, we are surrounded:
A silence already filled with noises,
A canvas on which emerges

A chorus of smiles, a winter morning.
Placed in a puzzling light, and moving,
Our days put on such reticence
These accents seem their own defense.

I find it exceptionally comfy, and this is a debut poet's work, no less.

Your comment is completely idiotic for multiple reasons.

1. He was 29 to 31 while writing these, not in his youth.
2. He never "discounted" any of these writings. The aims are high, that is all.
3. The writings are dear to him. A copy of the manuscript was practically all he took with him (certainly the only literature) while he travelled across the country during ww2. He also re-edited and re-publised them twice, the final time was 3 years before his death.
4. Around half of the essays, if not more, were not written by him. They were written by people who were real initiates and experts on specific topics. For example, di Giorgio was a very good initiate friend of Guénon.
5. In his interview he said that they were "indispensable" for someone looking to begin studying initiation from a Traditionalist perspective.

I'm not writing this for you. I'm writing it so people don't read your idiotic post and come to the wrong conclusions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21385589
I was very into esoterica as well, for quite a long time. Unfortunately, a lot of it is intentionally obscurantist. There is a reason most esoterica threads go like this:

>X position on Y
>"No, you don't understand Y. You're a plebian of the soul and don't have the astronomical IQ and spirit to understand Y."
>"No it is you who don't understand Y. You are a plebian of the soul and lack the astronomical IQ and soul to understand Y."

For a more historical and non-obscurantist take, check out the book Magee edited. It's a very straightforward look they frames the traditions within philosophy and science more generally.

A key thing in esoterica is appeals to tradition. You have to be taught the arts directly, by someone who already is initiated into them. Thus you get a lot of claims of people to have been initiated into secret orders. Also, since the market is small, a lot of people accusing each other of being frauds.

I'm not saying such groups didn't exist. They had a blooming period in the late 19th and early 20th century, but as far as groups that continued over the centuries, going much further back, there is essentially no evidence that they are real and lots of evidence that discovered "lost" tests and stories of such groups were made up by later authors. At worst, this is just fraud, but you can also consider it a sort of literary device.

Meditations on the Tarot always stood out to me as a good one. For your original question, you might find philosophy and science more interesting to your questions. Don't try to do a chronological slog through the "great names" or philosophy, that's a good way to get discouraged and bored.

The Great Courses Mind Body Philosophy is a great presentation on the mystery of consciousness in a world tending towards entropy. I would check out the information science course too, and The Ascent of Information. Information Theory is a huge paradigm shift that can connect all the sciences and it shows how the dialectical opposition of chaos and order, plus the mathematics of self organization, lead to life and evolution.

The Case Against Reality is another really good eye opener book.

Also, >>21386211 is right. If you link up with people to get "initiated" and do rituals, IME there is a very high frequency of people who want to feed you drugs, have a religious-like hold on you, and then try to buttfuck you. This seems true of the early 20th century occult wave too. Or they want you to bring your young female friends in so they can fuck them.

After that it is more a matter of taste but I love Zhukovsky, Balmont, Tolstoy, Turgenev, Chekhov, and Gogol. I dont know that much about russian literature, but I have a grasp on the basic shape as well as the rules of Russian poetry.

The reason I love Dostoevsky is that he combines an absolutely overwhelming love for humanity and existence, marred by periods of intense suffering, with a psychological acuity and a theatrical flair that creates these insane melodramatic sequences where the characters are practically shouting out the dialectics of the inner torments of his soul. The sequences in which Dmitri and Alyosha or Alyosha and Ivan basically scream at each other in TBK are among the most affecting things I have ever read. The Father Zosima death sequence may as well have been writtten by a mystic or prophet. He just completely understood the sense of simultaneous love for everything and confusion over the brokenness of everything and he managed to express this through the travails of the characters he has set up as kind of mouthpieces for aspects of human existence. The brothers and the father all represent magnified dimensions of personality(monk, rake, intellectual) which correspond also to basic principles of reality(the spirit, body, mind), but he has arranged them into this almost delirious theatre of circumstance where you lose track of whether the characters are even really being characters or just acting out some kind of conversation. His prose is overall not great but he does possess the ability to make you feel a sense of excitement and foreboding, a breathless anticipation, with the way he chops up his sentences and paragraphs with digressions and cutoffs, you are always fully attendant even when he goes on a 20 page detour about some minor character's backstory because you understand why this is important to the overall conversation being had by the voices of the novel.

He is not a first rate artist, but he is a monumental impact on literature. James Joyce thought he was the single biggest propulsion towards Modernist prose.

I apologize for grammar and diction errors in this post, not feeling the best mentally

>>21390283
>I'm just saying nobody talks and acts this way and while his characters are certainly eccentric and unique, they are not realistic at all.
I think this point would circumvent most of classical and traditional literature in favor of a fairly recent and specific style of realism.
Consider: Homer's Iliad. Goethe's Faust. Eschenbach's Parcival. They're literary epics. Nobody speaks in rhymed meter or verse, but this itself is part of the medium and form. It's like saying that humans don't perceive vision in 24 frames per second, ergo cinema is not realistic. It misses the purpose of form in art, even if that form is often accidental.
Realism, while a valid form and structure in art, is itself just one style. And realism itself can be used in spiritual and fantastic ways. Greek sculpture is very lifelike and 'realistic,' and to the layman it's more tangible feature is that it accurately depicts real human beings, in contrast to other kinds of sculptures. However, just looking at that, one would miss the true idealized and stylized nature of the work.

>>21388006
If you are alluding to Dostoevsky’s worst novels, then, indeed, I dislike intensely The Brothers Karamazov and the ghastly Crime and Punishment rigamarole. No, I do not object to soul-searching and self-revelation, but in those books the soul, and the sins, and the sentimentality, and the journalese, hardly warrant the tedious and muddled search. Dostoyevsky’s lack of taste, his monotonous dealings with persons suffering with pre-Freudian complexes, the way he has of wallowing in the tragic misadventures of human dignity – all this is difficult to admire. I do not like this trick his characters have of ”sinning their way to Jesus” or, as a Russian author, Ivan Bunin, put it more bluntly, ”spilling Jesus all over the place."Crime and Punishment’s plot did not seem as incredibly banal in 1866 when the book was written as it does now when noble prostitutes are apt to be received a little cynically by experienced readers. Dostoyevsky never really got over the influence which the European mystery novel and the sentimental novel made upon him. The sentimental influence implied that kind of conflict he liked—placing virtuous people in pathetic situations and then extracting from these situations the last ounce of pathos. Non-Russian readers do not realize two things: that not all Russians love Dostoevsky as much as Americans do, and that most of those Russians who do, venerate him as a mystic and not as an artist. He was a prophet, a claptrap journalist and a slapdash comedian. I admit that some of his scenes, some of his tremendous farcical rows are extraordinarily amusing. But his sensitive murderers and soulful prostitutes are not to be endured for one moment—by this reader anyway. Dostoyevsky seems to have been chosen by the destiny of Russian letters to become Russia’s greatest playwright, but he took the wrong turning and wrote novels.

>>21370500
His opposition to Christianity is mostly due to a desire to oppose the bourgeois intellectuals of his time. He certainly despises protestantism, but his position towards Catholicism is more ambivalent, and he recognizes christianity in the west as being basically romanized and germanised. >>21373688
The Traditionalist critique of Christianity is that it's a merely sentimental/moral religion, that the highest one can achieve within it is a vague mystical state (as Evola says, merely ecstatic and passive, without post-ecstatic and active "re-entry" into one's self, completing the self-conscious initiation process), and also that ANY AND ALL historical and eschatological events or revelations (like God giving his unique revelation to Moses, and later Christ's redemption, but also the ongoing fight against Satan's influence in this world) are inadmissible from a Traditional standpoint - because history means nothing from the Traditional standpoint, which is anti-eschatological, regarding eschatologies as particularist and exclusivist tribal myths that have become dogmas. Essentially, Traditionalism's critique of Christianity is very similar to the Theravada critique of Mahayana Buddhism's soteriological and eschatological elements.

But these criticisms potentially force Traditionalism itself into a passive and quietistic position, which it is supposedly criticizing Christianity for. If there is no collective mystery or collective quest for redemption or struggle against Satan, if religions can't have an eschatological, soteriological, world historical character, because the only real truth lies in the universal metaphysical truth attained through individual initiation, then why bother fighting the occult war at all? In fact this is where a lot of Guenonians end up, advocating just riding out the kali yuga because it's all cyclical anyway. If your conception of all human dealings, all history, is simply that it is samsara, with no teleological or eschatology, then your only two options for understanding samsara are (1) it's an uncreated and "static" eternal world, like Aristotle's world, or (2) it cyclically dies and is reborn, and presumably there is some symbolically "fixed" number and nature to the ages of the cycle and so on and so forth, but again all this means nothing, since as an individual initiate you cannot affect the cycles in any way, or perhaps at most you can accelerate the present one (?).

What is even the value in seeking to create a "diamond/rainbow body" and escape samsara at all? Why seek immortality? Why desire to order society according to divine models if it's all cyclical or indifferent anyway? Guenon and Evola both emphasize that there is nothing "moral" in what they are doing, and that the vulgar sentimental and moral religion of everyday faithful is merely exoteric, basically its only value is containing dumbed down versions of symbols that keep ordinary people anchored in their Traditional-Platonic republics, while maintaining pathways of symbolic ascent for talented individuals to pursue to their eventual initiation. But again, why? Unless there is some real, non-cylical, zero-sum struggle going on, then who cares? Why do things even happen contingently in history, like Evola says when he says that it's bizarre that such a sentimental religion took hold in the "active" West, if everything is cyclical?

It seems to me like there are contradictions in the Traditionalist worldview, because it wants to take history seriously, it wants to take the occult war seriously, it wants to be active in the world (except for some extreme Guenonians), it has or wants to have an eschatology, but it can't admit this to itself because it views all of these things as inadmissible in pure metaphysics. It's a bit like modern science in this way: science is unwilling to envision anything metaphysical, because it's obsessed with not tainting itself with superstitions. Similarly Traditionalism doesn't want to taint itself with mere samsaric, dogmatic, sentimental, tribal superstitions. But just like modern science closes itself off to genuine truths and opportunities, Traditionalism closes itself off to non-jnana possibilities that are more interesting than it imagines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21373693
For example, it closes itself off to angelology and demonology, to the idea that on higher metaphysical planes there are beings beyond the human (at least in part) who are both good and evil. Ironically it ends up "confusing the planes" itself, by assuming that the only thing between man and the Absolute is this metaphysical hierarchy of symbols, and that there are no other beings with plans for us, that the cosmos is a cyclically autorenewing stage on which a few Guenons and Evolas periodically become immortal (for what? where do they go? if it's just to a purified paradisiacal state, isn't that what they criticize Christianity for promising?). Most major traditions have some form of angelology/demonology, whether Neoplatonic or Christian, pre-Islamic djinn, Buddhist demonology, etc. From a Traditionalist perspective, a Christian or Neoplatonic angelology that emphasizes faith in and collaboration with Good beings who are actively engaged in an eschatological fight, an occult war, and who both want to help us and who want our help, would just be superstition. But from a Christian perspective, and from a Neoplatonic or even Mahayana perspective that takes the occult war seriously, Traditionalism would be dangerously "magical" in trying to be an amoral series of techniques, and advice for the maintenance of said techniques in initiatic lines, in a cosmos in which active participation in soteriological eschatology is a necessary element of any awakening, and in which demonic forces are equally active. From this perspective, Evola and Guenon would be doing exactly what they criticize New Agers for doing: stripping people of their everyday protections and throwing them into trans-personal psychic experiences in which they will simply be subject to whatever forces are nearby.

In rejecting all claims to revelation as contingent and samsaric, Traditionalism also misses out on the possibility of a symbolic interpretation of "dispensationalist" revelation, in which history is not merely samsaric and cyclical, and attaining enlightenment is not merely optional and always potentially open to amoral initiates, and the occult war is not merely a particularly bad patch in the most recent kali yuga in an infinite cycle of them, but instead, history is not cylical, there is a fixed goal here, there are win and lose conditions, enlightenment is not just "available" to initiates but is a responsibility and a duty, and thus enabling others to be enlightened is also a duty, etc.

And therefore, the mythic-eschatological content of a religion like Christianity, with its publically available emphasis on resisting Satan and imitating Christ in daily life, is not just an incidental exoteric form of symbols that are only really relevant to autistic initiates, there is actually a purpose to the "opening" of the mysteries, which, yes, vulgarized them from a certain perspective, but perhaps only because this was analogous to sprinkling thousands of seeds, formerly been contained in neatly condensed form in individual pots, over a huge field of soil and manure, so that at first they seem merely "lost," but in time they grow and become many thousands of fruit-bearing, seed-bearing trees themselves?

If all of history can be interpreted symbolically in this way, then we can begin to ask questions that the Traditionalists are afraid to ask: What does it MEAN, using symbolic interpretation and sympathetic intuition, that Christ figures appeared and managed to embed moral messages and fundamentally change history, turning pagan Europe into a moral and even sentimental Christian Europe - which Evola can only view as an aberration, from his Traditionalist perspective? What does it MEAN that analogous developments occurred in India, with Mahayana and other soteriological movements introducing new ideas into the stagnant and formalistic ritualistic cults? If this is all just samsaric "noise," (1) why would there be any "noise" that diverges from the cyclical norm, and (2) why care at all? It's just a blip in the cycle.

Traditionalist metaphysics in my view also has an impoverished account of metaphysical personality and of the metaphysics of freedom, but I've already written too much, sorry about that. But I find the dismissal of the encounter of personal beings in mystical states incomplete and even lazy. The "scientific" starkness of Traditionalism is very useful insofar as it burns away all the dangerous dross of, for example, Blavatsky's Theosophy's blind faith in its Masters of Wisdom, or Steiner's endless visionary claims with no proof. But it should have been a clearing and a praeparatio evangelica, not a self-sufficient technique to end all techniques. Overall I think Traditionalism needs a re-fertilization by all the traditions it rejects: Abrahamic, Zoroastrian, and Hindu bhakti. Its extreme rejection of personal, moral, eschatological, and soteriological elements was historically conditioned by the dangerous spread of New Age syncretism and occultism that led to people like Crowley (probably genuinely dangerous, as can be seen in Scientology). This process should be oriented toward fighting the occult war in a moral, soteriological, eschatological way. The presupposition of autistic initiation and meaningless cyclical samsara should be dropped, and the "merely accidental" elements of traditions (that is, that don't accord with autistic initiation and meaningless cyclicality) should be reinterpreted in this light.

>>21373703

This ties into the poverty of the Traditionalist understanding of personality and freedom: they only see these as sources or vehicles of contingency, to be purged so that the higher self can be brought forth, transcending contingency and leaving samsara. But personality and freedom are symbolically analogous to history: apparent contingency that can contain or reflect symbolic truth. Traditionalism sees all three of these categories in a merely negative way, each is interpreted as mere caprice or as the negative pole of manifestation of essence. But if the nature of all being is that of essence, which is pure in itself but which struggles to manifest clearly in becoming, then why shouldn't becoming itself (and its subordinate aspects: personality, freedom, history) have its own essence and meaning? Why not interpret ALL temporal contingency, all becoming qua "mere negation of, or derivation or divagation from, atemporal being," as itself the symbolic emanation of an essence that combines and explains both being and becoming, instead of merely LEAVING becoming as an empty/negative category as almost all nondualist metaphysicians, including Traditionalists, do? This inquiry would allow us to ask all the questions Traditionalists can't ask from within their own framework:
>Why does samsara/maya (the totality of Becoming as the mirror of the totality of Being) exist at all?
>Why do individual Persons (individual monads of Becoming, strung between equal possibilities of self-distancing from Being or self-purification and ascent to Being, undecidable except by the individual Person) exist at all, as distinct from the spheres of emanation?
>Why do individual souls perceive themselves as free (the right to Become Being, or not to Become non-Being, undecidable except by the Person)?
>What is the nature of non-human souls (monads of Becoming with higher grades of Being)?
>What is the nature of God (the Being that mirrors itself in Becoming), and why is Free Personality (the right to Become etc.) among the elements that stems from God, if it has no Being and no meaning?
while using the Traditionalists' refined methods of sympathetic symbolic intuition, just training it on the one symbol they most neglect.

>>21382003
Read Evola and you'll find out. I can't and won't summarise everything for you. What I can tell you is that Evola already had major gripes with the Jewish prophetic tradition, which is the deepest root of Christianity. The key to understanding the prophetic tradition is to acknowledge two things - first, that it belongs to a very profane culture, and second, that it originates from the lowest social stratum of that culture. So, whereas (at least the best) rabbis and Jewish kings had their own spiritual and royal arts, the prophets were mostly very pious and coarse bums. Their spirituality was that of a man who feels a strong, strong love for divinity, but also, due to his coarse mentality and special psychological features, fails to discover the presence of the divine element anywhere at all. Hence the difference between the Greeks who admired the world as a reflection of the divine world of forms on the one hand, and the Jewish prophets on the other hand, with the famous cry "vanitas vanitatum". In the prophetic view, God is the only thing of value, and he is not to be found anywhere, least of all within ourselves. Hence the fundamentally shattered and broken nature of man, who needs "redemption", and, what is more, faith in order to be redeemed. From this stems also the very flawed "solution, at every level - you just need to be rendered "complete" by "God". Orthodoxy provides the most successful formulation of this with the idea of the Godbearing man, and also of Theosis, but even that stops short of true metaphysical heights. God is beyond all form, beyond all manifestation and beyond any completeness or completing function. To unite with God means more than to honour him in your heart - it means to become one with him, literally, and consequently also transcend everything, as he does. That's henosis. If you don't reach that level, you are still dealing with manifestation rather than with the source, the essence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21394283
Hermetic neoplatonic metaphysics which he purports to find at the core of every orthodox religious tradition. Closest to Renaissance hermetic platonism if you need a frame of reference.

He himself preferred Europe's indigenous pagan tradition, not specifically for any of its cults or "dogmas," but basically something like the way India works, where particular cults and practices can rise and fall according to their accidental features and historical contingencies, but the basic premise underlying all of them is wisdom and insight into the metaphysical core of things. Thus India can sustain and did sustain apparently divergent traditions like Tantra, Buddhism, Hinduism, etc., all with a thousand subschools and boundaries too hazy to really even say they are distinct traditions at all, but all basically oriented toward the same perennial metaphysical core, and all predicated on actually achieving insight into this core in regular practice (at the highest levels).

Jefferson and Adams have a public tiff after Thomas Paine's Rights of Man is leaked. Adams accused of being a monarchist, kek.
>All of Abagail-Jefferson letters

Other than that, most of the pre-reconciliation letters are good if you're interested in the history of politics. The true kino comes after they're both retired and take up corresponding from 1812 until the end of their lives (both died on July 4, 1826.

It's undoubtedly some of the best writing from the United States. They're constantly discussing history, philosophy (both classical and modern), Napoleon, slavery and meditations on life and death. It's highly underrated /lit/.

The best string of letters start on January 20th, 1820 to the last letter on April 17th 1826.
They're both living in pursuit of Cicero's ideal lifestyle for elder statesmen as laid out in De Senectute. Two elderly gentlemen, who know they are destined for history, trying to one up each other in beautifully written English.

>Slavery in this Country I have seen hanging over it like a black cloud for half a Century, if I were as drunk with enthusiasm as Swedenborg or Westley I might probably say I had seen Armies of Negroes marching and countermarching in the air shining in Armour. I have been so terrified with this Phenomenon that I constantly said in former times to the Southern Gentleman, I cannot comprehend this object I must leave it to you, I will vote for forceing no measure against your judgements, what we are to see God knows and I leave it to him, and his agents in posterity. I have none of the genius of Franklin to invent a rod to draw from the cloud to its Thunder and lightning. I have long been decided in opinion that a free government and the Roman Catholick religion can never exist together in any nation or Country, and consequently that all projects for reconciling them in old Spain or new are Eutopian, Platonick and Chimerical. I have seen such a prostration and prostitution of Human Nature, to the Priesthood in old Spain as settled my judgment long ago, and I understand that in new Spain it is still worse if that is possible.

tldr: Highly recommend kino. Catholics, do not read. You will seethe

The people is sovereign and not subject to any foreign power

Catholicism isn't the problem with republicanism, the problem is that Catholicism has an earthly sovereign who lives in the Vatican and it creates the ambiguity that Catholics are subjects of the pope and not "of themselves" (as both subject and constitutor of a sovereign state). Early modern political theory took this kind of thing very seriously and functioned by envisioning something like the stage on which people are the ultimate subjects they are in the state of nature, and can't be reduced any further politically, and then envisioning what it means for people in that state to constitute themselves a free people, by "giving themselves the law." This is why Locke says that the state of nature continue to exist, i.e., all sovereign peoples are in a state of nature with respect to eachother just as all individuals were prior to the formation of any sovereign peoples.

If you have any other already constituted sovereignty to which people owe their ultimate obedience when supposedly constituting themselves a free and sovereign people, then it is a false constitution, because they gave erroneous assent to the formation of the body politic.

English and American political theory always had a huge fear of Catholic subversives, going back to the early days of the English Reformation when the church was dominated by the Habsburgs, who had just conquered and sacked Rome, and who wanted to end the Reformation by conquering and subduing the Protestants as rebels and heretics, including conquering England and pressing dynastic claims on it, famously culminating in the Battle of the Spanish Armada. That memory of "treacherous papists" and especially subversive Jesuits never died in England and led to fairly brutal persecutions of Catholics.

By the time of the 19th century Catholics often were from more rural and less bourgeois regions and gained the further stigma of being backwards, anti-Enlightenment, retarded bumpkins but also subversives who would ally with the pope and his infiltrator Jesuits and sell out the bourgeois nation-state at the drop of a hat.

>>21394522
If you are alluding to Dostoevsky’s worst novels, then, indeed, I dislike intensely The Brothers Karamazov and the ghastly Crime and Punishment rigamarole. No, I do not object to soul-searching and self-revelation, but in those books the soul, and the sins, and the sentimentality, and the journalese, hardly warrant the tedious and muddled search. Dostoyevsky’s lack of taste, his monotonous dealings with persons suffering with pre-Freudian complexes, the way he has of wallowing in the tragic misadventures of human dignity – all this is difficult to admire. I do not like this trick his characters have of ”sinning their way to Jesus” or, as a Russian author, Ivan Bunin, put it more bluntly, ”spilling Jesus all over the place."Crime and Punishment’s plot did not seem as incredibly banal in 1866 when the book was written as it does now when noble prostitutes are apt to be received a little cynically by experienced readers. Dostoyevsky never really got over the influence which the European mystery novel and the sentimental novel made upon him. The sentimental influence implied that kind of conflict he liked—placing virtuous people in pathetic situations and then extracting from these situations the last ounce of pathos. Non-Russian readers do not realize two things: that not all Russians love Dostoevsky as much as Americans do, and that most of those Russians who do, venerate him as a mystic and not as an artist. He was a prophet, a claptrap journalist and a slapdash comedian. I admit that some of his scenes, some of his tremendous farcical rows are extraordinarily amusing. But his sensitive murderers and soulful prostitutes are not to be endured for one moment—by this reader anyway. Dostoyevsky seems to have been chosen by the destiny of Russian letters to become Russia’s greatest playwright, but he took the wrong turning and wrote novels.

My parents are old enough to be alive in a time when public intellectuals would go on national late night tv talk show programs while watched by millions and millions of people, composer Leonard Bernstein got primetime specials bringing classical music to the masses, faithfully adapted televised versions of plays by people like Tennessee Williams were fairly common. Movies like The Godfather, Taxi Driver, One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest, 2001: A Space Odyssey, were in the upper echelons of the box office figures. Authors that topped the NYT best sellers' list were Kurt Vonnegut, Umberto Eco, John Cheever, John Steinbeck, Vladimir Nabokov, Saul Bellow, Irving Stone, Gore Vidal, etc.

Now it's just nonstop YA-for-30-year-old women Colleen Hoover coming of age schlock or mass produced Airport Bookstore Tom Clancy/James Patterson ghostwriter mysteries. Or "How to EPICLY UNF*CK YOURSELF AND HECKING WIN AT LIFERINO" or some liberal poltician cashing in with another autobiography.


Of course that's not to say it was all like that.
There's always been a large quantity of mindless crap when it comes to mass media and the majority of people tend to gravitate to middle of the road and lower tier of entertainment. But there was a more robust environment for "upper-middle brow" media to exist in the mid-20th century and reach mass audiences than there has been ever since.

In my estimation, far more people may be literate now than, say, 75 years ago, but most of those that are, particularly the well-to-do, seemof comparably low intellect and are basically enslaved to the most base impulse and consumerist tendency. Whereas at least at one point there was some elite class of highly functioning, curious and intelligent, semi-well rounded citizens (or aspiring to be such).

Honestly it probably is reasonable to blame George Lucas. Star Wars came out at the perfect time. Literature was in decline, rock music was being replaced by other genres, the film industry was recently reborn. >>21391267
Plodding, methodical, yet mystical and vibrant at turns; the repetitions and simplicities which at first appear gratuitous build into a kind of resonant semantic harmony when he displays his rare gift for metaphor in combination with his incomparable command of narrative development at certain key moments. You understand why he builds all these little phrases and ideas after merges the fragments into an almost cinematic expression.

Anna Karenina is the peak of his technical abilities but there is more of his soul in War and Peace. Andrei looking up at the sky at the battle and again at his estate, Natasha exclaiming about the moonlight, the Rostovs making little play and then the carriage ride home, pierre looking at the comet, etc it so full of these things it is ridiculous, they are so bursting with inexpressible meaning. The best thing he ever wrote though is also the most famous thing, "He stepped down, trying not to look long at her, as if she were the sun, yet he saw her, like the sun, even without looking". This is maybe the greatest use of metaphor ever in a novel. It is literally impossible to overrate this sentence. The way it comes about when Levin is meeting the object of his love who it becomes increasingly clear doesnt care about him magnifies the intensity of it tenfold. I dont think any other author has ever depicted the state of nervous romantic confusion as clearly as he does here; it is so vivid that reading it feels more real than your own memory. The implication of fretful sun worship and sin embedded in his lust, combined with the beauty and innocent longing of his romantic affectation. The inadequacy of his person that orients himself to her in a position of worshipper to god in the first place. It illustrates the entirety of their relationship in a single fragment, while simultaneously being a strikingly beautiful and immersive image that transports you into the scene. There is probably no better example of why Tolstoy is a genius, and it also contains his typical strange almost laboured sentence structure, like he is just ekeing things out from some predetermined arrangement.

He also has some interesting short stories and essays but my post is becoming too long. What I Believe and The 3 hermits are good examples of each

As a /lit/ poster from 4chan, I'm here to share some memes and discuss literature.

First of all, let's talk about the classic "I tried to read Ulysses but it was too hard so I just watched the movie" meme. We've all been there, right? James Joyce's Ulysses is a notoriously difficult read, and sometimes it's just easier to watch the movie instead.

Next up, we have the "I don't always read books, but when I do, I prefer classics" meme. This one hits close to home for many of us on /lit/. There's just something about the timeless wisdom of the classics that keeps us coming back for more.

And of course, we can't forget the "One does not simply walk into Mordor" meme. This one is perfect for all the Tolkein fans out there. Whether you're reading The Hobbit or The Lord of the Rings, you know that venturing into Mordor is no easy feat.

In conclusion, /lit/ is the place to be for all your literary memes and discussions. So grab your favorite book and join in on the fun!

>I view everything through the lens of evolution, the emergence of order and complexity from chaos.

Based, we are an extension of the creativity that is intrinsic to the universe, a way for the universe to create with itself.

Consider human consciousness as an evolutionary process where question, choice, and action correpond to mutation, selection, and reproduction. A question is an information-seeking act, in the broadest sense our sense-perception is the result of information-seeking acts of our nervous system, which continually mutates our consciousness by exposure to new experiences. We can also of course intentionally ask questions of ourselves and our experiences, and by following the resulting lines of inquiry apprehend new possibilities beyond our immediate reach that choice can dig its teeth into. Choice is a purely destructive act, the elimination of possibilities from a list according to some criterion, to favor choice at the expense of questioning is to cause a progressive whittling-down of variety until stagnation is reached.

A recommendation emerges from this: to nourish your conscious freedom, seek The Unknown.

>>21392443
I've had a funny experience. For most of my life I was the youngest child. And as my older brothers entered into adulthood, it was obvious from the outset that they were destined to be losers. They both now lean on me for personal and emotional support and see me as the guiding light or whatever. They're obviously insecure about it too.
But on the other hand, when I was about 15 my dad decided to have another child. He was born to a different mother and has grown up very differently than myself and my older brothers. We grew up with an uninvolved mother and my dad was at the time quasi absuive and neglectful. He had a laissez faire style of parenting and we were left to our own devices.
Now this much younger brother grew up with two very involved parents. My dad at this time way mellowed out and so isnt such a hard ass and his mom is one of thsoe tiger moms. The four of us began with all the same level of potential, but the neglect and abuse left myself and my older brothers very stunted. My youngest brother is now very skilled in music, top athlete in every sport he tries, and far academically ahead of his age. He's well socialized and popular and very confident.
He often asks me questions about what instruments I learned, or sports I played, or what my birthday parties were like. It's hard to find ways to explain to him that i never got to do any of those things.
I dont resentment him for it. I'm very happy that he has all of that. I feel no jealousy or envy, but I do feel resentment for my parents. I wasnt unambitious or anything. I remember desperstely asking my dad to enroll me in sports and to put me in music classes but he always told me he was too busy. And of course the bad home environment and constany moving left me unsure of myself and socially awkward. All my younger brother's success does is reveal to me what is and isnt healthy in family life, and what areas in my life are stunted, and what steps I need to take to improve.
