to get unfiltered you need to understand that poetry is not supposed to be read but performed. so you need to visualize the events not as if they really happened but as if they were being performed in front of you as a stage adaptation. it's the same reason shakespeare filters people because they imagine it as a movie and not as a unique live performance with lives and breathes and stretches itself out in front of you.


the goal is to fall in love with the characters because of the ability of the actors not because of the actual written words. try reading a play or screenplay and you won't get it either because art direction, costumes, cinematography and music composition are all very important for movie adaptations.

the "novel" is fairly new, 16th century ~ everything before then was about performing and entertaining the 200-300 people that would show up and buy a ticket and a rat on a stick.

for example, achillies was always played by a guy who would stuff his loincloth and a big part of the play is he would bend over in suggestive ways and spread his legs to the audience every time his "amazing" attributes were described and sung about. the implication being that everyone loved achillies because of his huge cock and not the other things they are listing. but this is completely lost in a textual only interpretation.

>Achilles = άκιλις = άκιλεύς
>άκι = AKEY pain (where we eventually get ACHE from)
>λις = λεύς = lis / leus (this is a clever pun, LIS is love, LEUS is lion, but PEUS is penis - and L and P's sound the same in spoken greek without more context)

so ACHILLIES as we say it was ACHILLEUS was actually ACHIPPEUS which literally means a painful lovely dicking.


all of this context is obscured and forgotten because the academic retards who study the text have inherited christian sensibilities and aren't native greek speakers. the greeks and medieval bards knew homeric epics were highly amusing and a series of dick jokes but people started taking this stuff way too seriously in the 1800s and no wonder it filters so many people today because they stripped all the double entenders and comedy away from it. there are thousands more examples like this from ancient and classic literature.

>>21393977
In Buddhism there is rebirth, in Dennettianism there isn't. So, the activity of the self isn't entirely reducible to observed correlations with brain activity, since there is an observer-illusion even beyond all that. Dennett's rationale is that the self is an illusion, due to existence of stuff like blindsight and scientific studies on brain activity responses that do not correspond to what we call a conscious reaction. However, in Buddhism, the person who perceives those things or is the test subject will actually be reborn into another layer of samsara, which is itself the warping of time-perception in the moments preceding death while what we perceive materially as DMT flooding your brain. So all of this "material" stuff actually happens multiple layers deep in a perceptual illusion, with all sorts of carryover from your "previous lives". Which also means that the non-self can't be proven with brain activity researches.

>The way a mirage looks like water is self-evident as well.

Socrates: I am afraid I do not follow here, Dennett. For you seem to be confusing two things as though they are one, mixing up what is naturally separate. First you would mix the idea of water up with its appearance, as you say that a man would try to drink a mirage. But do we not obviously distinguish between appearance and the thing? Let us consider this point a little closer. When you see water in the distance, what would you say?

Dennett: Why, Socrates, I would exclaim, "I can see water."

Socrates: And, to speak perfectly correctly, you would not say, "that is most certainly water."

Dennett: Why, Socrates, only if my reason had fled me.

Socrates: And so we maintain that there is a difference between what is seen, and what, we might say, is?

Dennett: It cannot be denied.

Socrates: And insofar as something is seen, we have established that we can only rightly comment on our relationship with the thing, in this case that it is merely seen? And to know what an object is requires some other kind of knowledge. This much we acknowledge?

Dennett: I'm not sure I follow you, Socrates, but I will consent.

Socrates: Let me put it this way: do we not distinguish between the sight of water and water itself only in point of its being? When we drink water, even if it tastes as we expect, we would be more confident in asserting that this substance is, in fact, water. And would we not rightly assent that such a substance is in fact what we believe it be?

Dennett: Necessarily.

Socrates: And do we admit the perception of falsities? I mean errors of sight, for example the little transparent letters we occasionally see floating before our eyes? We admit that these are false sights?

Dennett: Why, Socrates, one might affirm they are false in reality, but how could they be false as far as sight is concerned?

Socrates: You have led me along the path my own mind was just taking me, Dennett. But ought we to call the mere sight true or false? Surely it is a sight, but whether it is true or false we cannot say. We must admit truth and falsity pertain to the reality of a thing.

Dennett: You have said what I had in thought but could not put into words, Socrates!

Socrates: And so, in point of fact, the perception itself, for example the sight of water, is neither true nor false. It is only when we connect this with an idea that it gains truth or falsity. And in so far as a perception conforms with an idea, we say it is true, and in so far as a perception does not conform, we say that it is false, this is given?

Dennett: Certainly.

Socrates: And so we must admit then that we have no more right to assert that consciousness is a unified field than we do that it is a multiplicity, or nothing at all, if we are to gauge its reality or non-reality on our sight, or any other sense we may have. Neither would it be correct to say that the water we see with our eyes or taste with our mouths is the water we assert it to be, but rather that it is something which, perhaps, cannot be seen nor felt nor tasted, if we want to speak of it unequivocally. And it is precisely what is good which allows water to be what it ought to be, as we say of something which meets its idea.

Dennett: I am reluctant, but I cannot deny what has been said.

Socrates: And so, Dennett, we admit that, in order to have these beliefs at all and to be able to see the like from the unlike and the equal from the unequal, we say that these things which are equal, beautiful and good really do exist. And what of our soul? It is not the proper place to venture to deep on this question, but we must admit that we do see things, and we know the equal, the unequal, the like and the unlike, as things which are already in us, which enable us to know the being of water. And so, while we do not, as the Delphic Apollo says, "know ourselves", we at least know its likeness. And is it not the goal of the philosopher to really know its being, as it might be the goal of the natural philosopher to really know the being of water, among other things?

>>21389769
For Tibetan Buddhism, Chögyam Trungpa Rinpoche’s collected works are cool to have.

>but his character!

This is a valid point to bring up, but he still did a massive and wonderful service in bringing Tibetan Buddhist teachings to the West in English form. And, like it or not, Vajrayana does indeed include teachings on the transmutation of actions regarded in traditional Buddhism as defilements (sexual intercourse, consumption of liquor and psychoactive substances, eating meat), much like the vamamarga (“left-hand path”) of Hindu Tantric sects.

If you want a Western academic survey of Tibetan Buddhist mythology, symbolism, lore, rites, teachings and practices, Edwin Bernbaum’s “The Way to Shambhala” is also a good one.

posts.name: S10241875
posts.com:
>>21389769
Too large and confusing topic(s) to be covered in a book or multiple books. It is rather a methodical study, starting from the foundations of Vedic culture on the one hand and the shamanistic traditions of Central Asia on the other hand. A book that is good in one area may be useless in another.
Mayby
Joshi Lal Mani - Studies in The Buddhistic Culture of India during the seventh and eighth centuries A.D.
(A good overview of Buddhist culture during the heyday of the Indian Vajrayana and an understanding of the reasons for its decline. Not about the Himalayas.)

>Tantric traditions
Jacob P. Dalton - The Taming of the Demons: Violence and Liberation in Tibetan Buddhism - 2011
Well, this book is clearly not for beginners in the Vajrayana.

>or example Shingon Buddhism in Japan
Shingon Text - Kūkai , Kakuban - 2004 (BDK English Tripitaka)

>Bonpo
Per Kvaerne - The Bon religion of Tibet: the iconography of a living tradition - 1996
Namkhai Norbu has several books about Bon...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21389769
There's a lot of overlap between Saivism and the Vajrayana Buddhism in Tibet basically as two sides of the tantric movement (not in a left-hand vs right sense but "Hinduism" vs Buddhism). I'd recommend:
Snellgrove, Indo-Tibetan Buddhism
Davidson, Indian Esoteric Buddhism
Landaw & Weber, Images of Enlightment
Kinsley, The Ten Mahavidyas
For Shingon there's Abe, The Weaving of Mantra, the BDK translations of Kūkai and Kakuban as this anon noted >>21392409 and it would also be worth reading the Vairocanabhisambodhi sutra. Of course, medieval Buddhist literature isn't going to make much sense without a foundation in early Buddhist and Mahayana Buddhist thought, for which I'd recommend at least reading some of the nikayas and Nagarjuna. For suvey literature on Buddhism see Conze, Buddhism Its Essence and Development.
